item.title: Nuclear-free Mongolia a ‘symbol of peace in a troubled world’: Guterres
item.description: In a visit to Mongolia on Tuesday, Secretary-General António Guterres underscored the UN’s full solidarity for the country, which he described as “a symbol of peace in a troubled world”.

item.title: Heat, drought and wildfires during one of the warmest Julys on record– WMO
item.description: Amidst extreme heat, drought and wildfires, many parts of the world had just experienced one of three warmest Julys on record, the UN weather agency said on Tuesday.

item.title: Giraffes, parrots, and oak trees, among many species facing extinction
item.description: Around one million species are facing extinction, according to a report from IPBES, an independent intergovernmental science and policy body supported by the UN.

item.title: WMO reports decrease in likelihood of severe Atlantic hurricane season ahead
item.description: As the North Atlantic hurricane season enters its traditional peak period, the US National Atmospheric and Oceanic Administration (NOAA) has adjusted its forecast to monitor the conditions which impact cyclonic activity, according to the UN weather agency, WMO, on Friday.

item.title: Nuclear technology helps Mexico eradicate invasive insect pest
item.description: One of the most devastating insect pests infesting fruits and vegetables in Mexico has been eradicated in the state of Colima, according to the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).

item.title: UN chief slams ‘immoral’ profiteering amid global energy crisis
item.description: As the war in Ukraine continues to rage, skyrocketing energy prices are compounding an existential cost-of-living crisis for hundreds of millions of people, the UN chief said on Wednesday, introducing the third is a series of briefings from the Global Crisis Response Group (GCRG) on Food, Energy and Finance.

item.title: Horn of Africa faces most ‘catastrophic’ food insecurity in decades, warns WHO
item.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Tuesday that the Greater Horn of Africa is experiencing one of the worst hunger crises of the last 70 years.

item.title: American west faces water and power shortages due to climate crisis: UN environment agency
item.description: Two of the largest reservoirs in the United States are at dangerously low levels due to the climate crisis and overconsumption of water, which could affect water and electricity supply for millions in six western states and Mexico, the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) warned on Tuesday.

item.title: From The Field: Protecting the last Malayan tigers
item.description: The Malayan tiger is a critically endangered species, at a real risk of extinction, mainly as a result of illegal poaching and wildlife trafficking: according to the Malaysian authorities, fewer than 200 are left.

item.title: UN General Assembly declares access to clean and healthy environment a universal human right
item.description: With 161 votes in favour, and eight abstentions*, the UN General Assembly adopted a historic resolution on Thursday, declaring access to a clean, healthy and sustainable environment, a universal human right.

item.title: FAO warns 90 per cent of Earth’s topsoil at risk by 2050
item.description: A full 90 per cent of the Earth’s precious topsoil is likely to be at risk by 2050, according to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization, FAO.

item.title: Global awareness critical to protect world’s mangroves: UN science chief
item.description: Time is running out to protect the world’s mangroves which are not only home to many species but also an important hedge against climate impacts, the head of the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) said on Tuesday.

item.title: Why the UN General Assembly must back the right to a healthy environment
item.description: In late July, the UN General Assembly is expected to vote on a draft resolution recognizing the human right to a clean, healthy and sustainable environment.

item.title: Mega-drought, glacier melt, and deforestation plague Latin America and the Caribbean
item.description: From the Amazon to the Andes and the snowy depths of Patagonia, extreme weather and climate change are causing mega-drought, extreme rainfall, deforestation and glacier melt across the Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) region, according to a UN report published on Friday.

item.title: Climate change: New approach needed to gauge animal health impact on emissions
item.description: Animal health is important to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions, but greater investment is needed to evaluate the impact, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and partners said in a report published on Thursday.

item.title: ‘Moment for Nature’ essential to beat back threats, spur climate action
item.description: With less than eight years remaining to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, the President of the UN General Assembly convened a ‘Moment for Nature’ debate on Tuesday to examine the interconnected environmental threats hampering efforts to achieve sustainable development.

item.title: WMO warns of frequent heatwaves in decades ahead
item.description: Extreme heat in western Europe is causing devastating wildfires in France and Spain, unprecedented drought in Italy and Portugal, and the United Kingdom recorded its highest-ever temperature of just over 40 degrees Celsius during Tuesday, at London’s Heathrow airport.

item.title: Record 40°C UK temperatures linked to climate change: WMO
item.description: The chances of seeing unprecedented temperatures of 40 degree Celsius (40°C) or more in the UK could be up to 10 times more likely in the current climate than under a “natural climate unaffected by human influence,” the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) declared on Monday.

item.title: Kenya’s Kuruwitu corals are back, thanks to local conservation drive
item.description: A small, quiet village in Kenya has found a new purpose in the fishing industry through a successful marine coral conservation project, the first of its kind in the Marine Protected Areas of the western side of the Indian Ocean.

item.title: UN report: Value of nature must not be overridden by pursuit of short-term profit
item.description: The values that we ascribe to nature are vital parts of our cultures, identities, economies, and ways of life, all of which should be reflected in policy decisions surrounding our natural world, according to a new UN-backed report released on Monday.

item.title: From the Field: 'Bioprospecting'; Cambodia’s sustainable gold rush
item.description: Prospecting used to be about digging up gold and other minerals. Today “bioprospecting” is allowing countries to use the natural riches at their disposal, for the production of pharmaceuticals, and other commercially viable products.

item.title: Convergence of conflicts, COVID and climate crises, jeopardize global goals
item.description: Intersecting global crises are threatening the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and impacting food supplies, health, education, and security across countries worldwide, according to a new UN report released on Thursday.

item.title: UN and UEFA score Sustainable Goals as women’s Euro tournament kicks off
item.description: On Wednesday, the first day of the Women’s Euro 2022 football tournament, the United Nations launched Football For The Goals (FFTG), an initiative aimed at tapping into the power of the game to raise awareness of the Sustainable Development Goals, the UN’s blueprint for a fairer, greener future.

item.title: The Caribbean is ‘ground zero’ for the global climate emergency: Guterres
item.description: The UN Secretary-General’s final day in Suriname began on a small plane and ended at a podium. A 90-minute flyover from Paramaribo into the Central Suriname Nature Reserve revealed to António Guterres the astounding beauty of the Amazon but also spotlighted the threats the rainforest is facing from mining and logging activities, and climate change.

item.title: Suriname gives ‘hope and inspiration to the world to save our rainforests’: UN chief
item.description: Suriname might be the smallest and least populated country in South America, but it is also one of the greenest. Considered a global leader in biodiversity conservation, with more than 90 per cent of its land surface covered by native forests, the nation’s unrivaled natural resources more than make up for its size.

item.title: What COVID-19 taught us about risk in a complex, inter-connected world
item.description: A new UN report has shed fresh light on the ways that the COVID-19 pandemic unleashed cascading risks, particularly on vulnerable people, worldwide.

item.title: UN Ocean Conference ends with call for greater global commitment to address dire state of the ocean
item.description: Following a week of discussions and events in Lisbon, Portugal, the UN Ocean Conference concluded on Friday, with governments and heads of state agreeing on a new political declaration to Save Our Ocean.

item.title: With mangrove conservation, Kenya’s coastal communities plant seeds for sustainable ‘blue growth’
item.description: The southern ocean border of Kenya and Tanzania is dotted with thick hedges of mangroves – indispensable carbon sinks and spectacular ecosystems teeming with life – that appear to float dreamlike over creek beds and mudflats. These hardy trees and shrubs, and the communities that depend on them, are getting a major boost from UN-backed restoration plans that are also helping to reduce poverty and build economic resilience.

item.title: US Supreme Court ruling on environmental protection ‘a setback in our fight against climate change’
item.description: The ruling by the United States Supreme Court against the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on Thursday, is “a setback in our fight against climate change” said the UN Spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric.

item.title: New UN financing initiative goes live to power climate action
item.description: A new UN-led financing tool to strengthen weather and climate forecasting, improve life-saving early warning systems, safeguard jobs, and underpin climate adaptation for long-term resilience, officially opened for business on Thursday.
